div1.p: Russell suggests that Carter should find an assistant to help her with her work on the History of Yellow Fever manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, March 13, 1928

March 13, 1928
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
I thank you for your letter of the 9th of
March. I have also had the pleasure of seeing Dr. Thayer
and learning from him that you have already begun the work
again, which indicates, of course, that you are better. I
hope that your improvement will continue and that you will
have no more trouble.

The suggestion that you make about getting an assist-
ant in Washington seems to be an admirable one. Will you not
go ahead and see what can be done about getting an assistant,
and what and how the assistant will have to be paid. I would
like to consider the assistant as yours rather than ours, and
have no dealings with him or her except through you. As soon,
therefore, as you have news for us of the possibility of tak-
ing up the work again in Washington, please let me know. You
realize, of course, that you can count upon our help in every
possible way.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, F.F. Russell Miss Laura Carter
The Johns Hopkins Hospital
Room 201 - Marbury
Baltimore, Md.
